audio_caption: A male speaker with a neutral, informative tone discusses the countdown to the next GOP primary in South Carolina, referencing a new poll with results for Romney, Gingrich, and Ron Paul, noting an eleven-point surge for Paul. The speaker announces Congressman Paul will be joining live shortly. A short burst of triumphant, celebratory music plays, featuring brass instruments, before the male speaker returns, welcoming listeners back to the Kettle Report.

The clip opens with a male speaker introducing the topic of Congressman Ron Paul's performance in New Hampshire and his message. He asks if the GOP can find a home for Paul's principles and introduces Paul. Before beginning the discussion, he plays a clip from Senator Jim DeMint. The clip ends without further sounds.

The clip features a male speaker stating that "Ron Paul is the only one willing to say we really need to cut the budget and we need to...cut some of the functions of the Federal Government." He goes on to say that "Republicans must recognize that Ron Paul's message of limited government, individual liberty, more accountability at the Federal Reserve, better monetary policy" are important. Another male speaker with a conversational tone references the previous speaker, saying "Congressman Paul, you heard the influential Senator Jim DeMint." He then asks Congressman Paul if he believes there's room in the GOP for his principles.

The clip begins with a single male speaker who says, "Well, they're better be or there won't be much left for the party because..." The speaker discusses the fundamentals they claim to have believed in for a long time, mentioning "cutting spending," "balancing budgets," and "sound money." His tone sounds concerned and frustrated. He references failures to follow through on these principles, particularly in the past, and expresses the need to "pay attention" to those who believe in free markets and not "just give lip service" to them. The speaker implies negative consequences if those principles aren't adhered to.

The clip starts with a male speaker addressing someone, mentioning "Congressman," followed by the name "Charles Krauthammer." He notes that Krauthammer wrote a complimentary article about the person he's addressing, and he wants to discuss one of the article's key points.

The audio begins with a male speaker engaged in what sounds like an interview, directly addressing an interviewee about the possibility of delivering a keynote speech and pushing principles. The speaker then directly asks the interviewee if they would do that, and if it's something that appeals to them. A second male voice, presumably the interviewee, responds affirmatively, emphasizing he doesn't want the speech written for him. He appreciates Charles' comments and notes that Charles is a fellow physician. He expresses interest in writing the speech if given the chance. The interviewer then transitions to the topic of South Carolina, noting its pro-defense stance and contrasting it with the interviewee's anti-war message.

The clip starts with a conversation between two individuals. One speaker, a male, asks if there will be difficulties regarding a defense message for South Carolina primary voters. The other speaker, also a male, responds in a calm and measured tone, saying that he does not think so, citing advertisements and financial support from active military personnel and veterans. He argues that not everyone in the military wants to expand war and feels that people should go to the military to defend the country, especially in fighting wars that are declared or under a UN banner, or NATO, where people may not grow tired of the financial crisis. The first male speaker then states that the other man has been avoiding attacking Mitt Romney regarding private equity companies.

The clip begins with an interview, featuring one male speaker questioning another. The speaker mentions "Gingrich and Perry", and asks why Mitt Romney isn't being attacked. The interviewee then responds, explaining that he is "willing to attack him on policies". He clarifies that he doesn't want to attack him on "Bain's", as he believes that it's part of how the market works. He then mentions that people who are attacking Romney on the issue "either don't understand economics or demagoguing the issue for trying to make a political point". The interviewee then states that he defended Mitt in that case, as it's "very important that you cleanse a system". He goes on to provide a hypothetical situation regarding bankruptcy and restructuring, then briefly mentions a misquote. The clip concludes with the interviewer posing a "fed question". The interview is clear and professional throughout.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing the Federal Reserve meeting minutes from five years ago, highlighting that Bernanke and his colleagues missed the financial and housing meltdown, quoting Bernanke as saying "it is unlikely to see growth derailed by the housing market." The speaker sounds critical and analytical.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker inquiring about the Federal Reserve's economic misses, despite employing numerous PhD economists. Another male responds that the economists "follow the wrong ideas" and don't consider business cycles in relation to the Fed's actions. He states that they would have to "indict themselves" otherwise. He continues by mentioning Greenspan and describes a state of "total denial".

The clip begins with a male speaker asserting that "Austrian economists...explain this." He speaks with conviction, referring to bubbles and the necessity of economic correction, stating that interfering with correction prolongs it. He emphasizes the need for understanding the business cycle. He notes the incentive for economists to align with the Fed's viewpoint.

The audio begins with a male speaker urgently emphasizing the lack of "independence," cautioning against expecting "independent thinking at the Federal Reserve." He asserts that they are there to "defend a policy" he deems a "total failure" and calls for change. A second male voice, sounding agreeable and upbeat, thanks the speaker, referring to him as "Congressman Ron Paul," wishes him "good luck on the campaign trail," and expresses appreciation for his appearance.
